content.body: Does anyone know if there's a way to get the original/real dimensions of an image on an Image/ before the browser does its 'intervention' - ie the image in the file that is served by the web server?
Max: https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/embedded-content.html#dom-img-naturalwidth maybe
or https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/embedded-content.html#dom-img-naturalwidth-dev is a better link I guess (so-called “domintro”, specifically for developers)
or maybe even better, https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/HTMLImageElement/naturalWidth and https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/HTMLImageElement/naturalHeight
https://browser.engineering/ looks cool.

> <@foolip:matrix.org> https://browser.engineering/ looks cool.

Nice to see that it’s written in markdown (some flavor of markdown at least)
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @foolip:matrix.org
https://browser.engineering/ looks cool.

content.body: Needing to escape the HTML markup of every HTML example you want to put into would seem to make HTML a bad choice for as the source for a book about the creating or processing content for the web…
Not sure how many people know yet that the plan for MDN is to move all the MDN sources to markdown
It would be nice if one day most specs are written in markdown rather than HTML
I thought Bikeshed already fully supported writing spec source fully in markdown — but I can’t say I’ve seen any specs yet that are fully written in markdown (including any CSS specs)

specs with Bikeshed sources seem to all still have h1-h6 and `

` etc.
content.formatted_body: specs with Bikeshed sources seem to all still have h1-h6 and <p> etc.

content.body: * Needing to escape the HTML markup of every HTML example you want to put into a book about the web would seem to make HTML a bad choice for as the source for a book about creating or processing content for the web…

m.new_content.body: Needing to escape the HTML markup of every HTML example you want to put into a book about the web would seem to make HTML a bad choice for as the source for a book about creating or processing content for the web…

content.body:
I don't use `

`, but if you're going to add an ID anyway, there's not much of a win in using markdown for headers
content.formatted_body: I don't use <p>, but if you're going to add an ID anyway, there's not much of a win in using markdown for headers

content.body: ah yeah that makes sense
Also not sure how to do `<div algorithm>` and `<dfn>` in md
content.formatted_body: Also not sure how to do <div algorithm> and <dfn> in md

content.body: luckily, for MDN we don’t have need for `<div algorithm>`, and not much need for `<dfn>`
content.formatted_body: luckily, for MDN we don’t have need for <div algorithm>, and not much need for <dfn>

content.body: I honestly can't get myself very excited about Markdown over HTML, there's a lot of things to remember and gotchas either way. But I'm happy to go along with it since other people seem to like it :)
well, to me, the biggest win for MDN is not needing to escape code examples
it’s just very ugly and very error-prone
Yeah, that's nice, I guess it will use ``` instead?
right
and automatically get syntax highlighting
hmm, well, while I think of it, another huge win is that I’m no longer forced by style policy to use `<strong>` and `<em>` instead of just `<b>` and `<i>`
content.formatted_body: hmm, well, while I think of it, another huge win is that I’m no longer forced by style policy to use <strong> and <em> instead of just <b> and <i>

content.body: markdown is at least better than the weird HTML-but-not thing that the HTML spec uses
well, bikeshed specs arguably use even more weirdly HTML-but-not syntax
Particuarly the mix of "we just invented the `<ref>` element" and  "internal links are now written as `<span data-x=target>` because `x` isn't a real attribute"
content.formatted_body: Particuarly the mix of "we just invented the <ref> element" and "internal links are now written as <span data-x=target> because x isn't a real attribute"

content.body: ah yeah that stuff is ugly

another thing we’ve been doing for the MDN sources in preparation for moving to markdown is, trying to figure out if/how to replace background colors in tables with something that achieves the same effect

an example of something that got changed for that reason is the **Sameness Comparisons** table at https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Equality_comparisons_and_sameness#a_model_for_understanding_equality_comparisons
content.formatted_body: an example of something that got changed for that reason is the Sameness Comparisons table at https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Equality_comparisons_and_sameness#a_model_for_understanding_equality_comparisons

content.body: previously the cells there had either green or red backgrounds
but it got replaced with  ✅ U+2705 WHITE HEAVY CHECK MARK and  ❌ U+274C CROSS MARK emoji
I claim it’s actually an improvement — but I can imagine others might not agree
* but those background colors got replaced with  ✅ U+2705 WHITE HEAVY CHECK MARK and  ❌ U+274C CROSS MARK emoji

m.new_content.body: but those background colors got replaced with  ✅ U+2705 WHITE HEAVY CHECK MARK and  ❌ U+274C CROSS MARK emoji

content.body: Just spotted https://html.spec.whatwg.org still says "Join us on IRC, #whatwg on Freenode", which links to https://wiki.whatwg.org/wiki/IRC which redirects to https://whatwg.org/irc, but both should probably redirect to https://whatwg.org/chat and the spec page also just link to /chat and say 'Chat with us, Matrix or IRC', or similar. Not exactly urgent :-)
Well, that's more verbose than I'd expected.
Good catch

Where are the constructor steps for "Event" defined in the HTML spec? Can't find them anywhere in https://dom.spec.whatwg.org/#interface-event. Specifically looking for the initialization steps for `timeStamp`.
content.formatted_body: Where are the constructor steps for "Event" defined in the HTML spec? Can't find them anywhere in https://dom.spec.whatwg.org/#interface-event. Specifically looking for the initialization steps for timeStamp.

content.body: https://dom.spec.whatwg.org/#constructing-events says a lot of stuff
I think it’s like this to deal with init dicts in a single place
Ah... thanks :-)

> <@everyos:matrix.org> ---

First, its impressive whenever an external person shows up with a CL in crbug.  Second, its extra impressive for someone to take a vague 1-line problem statement and turn it into a complete working solution.  So well done!  (And I work at google and often can't get UX feedback because they are so busy, so extra well done for engaging so well with them!)
